description.text:
Fixes 3 major problems with the heated bed on the Creality CR-10.

  1. The bed support springs are in contact with the aluminium bed and in my case touches one of the heater traces. Eventually it will short out the heater.
  2. When the bed is set to 0.2 mm height from the hot end the springs have very little tension
  3. The bed will wobble on the springs in the original configuration.

Solution:

  1. Provides a 2mm pad between the spring and the Heated Bed.
  2. Compresses the springs by an additional 4 mm
  3. Provides a low tolerance guide for the bed to be adjusted and thus eliminates all bed wobble.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print in PETG or ABS as PLA will not withstand the heat of the heated bed.

Assembly
  1. The spring goes in the male part.
  2. The male part goes into the female part.
  3. The whole assembly is positioned under the bed between the bed and the carriage with the large end towards the carriage.

description.text:
Used CAD to design molds, then used laser to cut molds, then laminated the proprietary "stack" of polymers and molded the "stack" into the 3D textured sheet with the molds, then placed finshed molded sheet into laser bed and used same mold files to cut the contour of the molded shape.
Easily make molds for phone covers (shown) logos, signage, lettering, pickguards (shown) etc. Same CAD file cuts the sheets according to contour of original mold graphic.

Little more info

I need to keep the process a little sketchy, as it is my invented laminate, and tried to get a patent, but only using trade secret right now. The process of molding the sheets and cutting along same mold outline is not as proprietary, but still need to keep it simple. Kindof like printing a graphic using a drawing file, then cutting the outline of the printed graphic with a plotter, using same but altered file.

Basically I laminate dichroic films and special effect films for a living, mostly architectural commercial glass and commercial signage. Recently figured out how to laminate textures without glass, and using PET films instead, then lasering out the sheet, cutting letters for signage, or phone case covers. The laminate is multi-layered with resins, capped by PET film, then back is filled with urethane, then self adhesive film is applied so that the phone covers (or letters for signage) are peel-and-stick.

The process opens up entirely new markets.

title: Rickenbacker 325 Guitar Homage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A fully functional 3d printed electric guitar. Made as an homage to the Rickenbacker 325 played by John Lennon in the early Beatles. The files included here are for the body, pickguard, knobs, neck, and fretboard. The neck will need a larger heel added to it to fit into the cavity of the body (note: this is different from the neck I built which has an aluminum armiture for strength).
This was an ambitious build, about 50 hours of printing and 50 hours of assembly and finishing. Plus over 100 hours of CAD design.
To learn more see the video above. WARNING: it's an hour long video with lots of theory and practical info. Or, scroll forwards to last 15 minutes and see a four song performance featuring this fantastic guitar.
The pickups shown above are not 3D printed, but I did print a pickup as an exersize to prove it couls be done. See it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2598645

Printer:

MakerFarm 12" i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm per layer

Infill:

Varies. 20% typical, but higher where needed.

Massive amounts of assembly and finishing were required (about 50 hours) It could be left "natural" as shown in the one photo above, but I chose to bodywork and paint it for a more attractive finish.
Learn more about it here:

description.text:
These three parts assemble together with a 3/4 x 1 3/8 inch radial bearing (common hardware item) to create a roller hook that fits cords up to 7/8 inch diameter. ABS is best because ABS glue creates a strong bond between the inner and outer halves. The center piece simply fits snug into the radial bearing. Purpose of the roller hook is for hanging a charge cord to an electric vehicle (EV).

For more information on the whole EV accessory, go to:
https://boltingforthreeyears.blogspot.com/2017/10/charge-cord-roller-hook.html

title: Coolant Cap Wrench for Ford, Lincoln, Mazda, Volvo, Land Rover

description.text:
I made this for our 2014 Ford Escape's coolant reservoir cap. It can be a bit hard to turn and is tucked in a somewhat awkward spot and this tool helps a lot.

It should fit many newer Ford models. I think it may also fit some Mazda, Volvo, Land Rover as I saw a tools for sale online that supposedly work on all these brands. I can only confirm it works on my Ford. If you find it works on other vehicles, let me know and I can add that information.

It fits easily with just a little tolerance. I added a 3/8" square drive hole on the handle for a socket wrench just in case you need a little extra torque, which I doubt you will.

If your cap is just under 60mm in diameter at the outside of the 6 ribs and is ~55 mm diameter at their base, then this should work for you.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Flip it text side down.

I printed mine out of PETG with:
.2mm layers
3 perimeters (.4mm nozzle)
6 top and bottom layers
15% rect infill

It seems plenty strong enough.

These cases are compatible with the following Feather boards:

Adafruit Feather HUZZAH with ESP8266 WiFi: https://www.adafruit.com/product/2821

Adafruit HUZZAH32 – ESP32 Feather Board: https://www.adafruit.com/product/3405

Feather ESP8266

Top Cover

Select one of the following (with an .stl extension):

cover-feather-slotted: Case cover with slots cut in the top for wire. The end slots can be used for fishing in wiring that has already been attached/soldered during prototyping.

cover-feather-top-closed: Fully covered/closed top.

cover-feather-slotted-top-hold: If your machine doesn't print the bottom cases' pins quite right, snap off the top portion and use this cover (it presses against the USB port and PCB antenna, so preferably use this as a last option).

Bottom Case

Select one of the following (with an .stl extension):

feather-esp8266-bottom-closed: Case with no cutouts for headers.

feather-esp8266-bottom-slotted: Case with cutouts on the bottom for headers.

feather-esp8266-bottom-header-shrouded: A flipped case for boards that have male headers soldered for breadboarding. Use with any top and female dupont-style headers.

Feather ESP32

The ESP32 shares top covers with the ESP8266, so pick any of the ones above and add a bottom case.

Top Cover

Select a cover from the ESP8266 section above.

Bottom Case

esp32-feather-bottom: This case has the rear pins cut in 'half' so that they fit, since the ESP32 Feather module covers part of the rear holes. Some rework may be needed post-print depending on filament/printer tolerances (or just snap them off and try the top-hold cover).

esp32-feather-bottom-slotted: An ESP32 case with slots for headers going out the bottom.

Si7021 Humidity/Temperature Sensor Breakout Case

The top and bottom of the Si7021 Humidity/Temperature Sensor case are designed around this specific board: https://www.adafruit.com/product/3251

author: JobSmolders

description.text:
All, My first real go at a remix of sorts. blending in what others have done.and what I would have done.

This is the plain model. based on a CR-10 mount for those wishing to goto a E3D V6 Hot end.
the offsets are as close as can be from the factory hot end. (not the same just close)

The fan for the Hot end is a direct mount 40mm fan. and imho optimized to keep the hot end cool.

The blower assembly is a one piece modular unit no screws necessary. it snaps on. uses a 40mm top mounted fan. its gonna blow! (I may mix in a 50mm fan version for those who just want a 50mm but Im pretty sure it would be a wast of a perfectly good setup. not to mention the 50mm version would take up more space and weight.

Plans. I intend on making a dovetail mount of sorts for a ABL or sensor for those that will inevitably want one. (I personally don't use one. their buggy imho).

I have printed many of these to see and hold the parts.
The ones I have printed were: test fitted to "my CR-10. And, they do fit"

I did my best to design the parts so they were 1: functional, reliable, light weight & have the least amount of foot print.

My print settings.
layers .2 (I did it to see the finer resolution (again for prototyping reasons)
4 layers top and bottom.
I chose to go with 50% infill

Supports (at your discretion) I used them. I think most of the parts would print without them
if your printer has good bridging capabilities. But In my attempt to see the part first hand I elected to go with supports.

I also printed my test is PLA.

Perhaps Ill print one in ABS or ??? time permitting.

feed back is appreciated, as well as a pic upload should you print one.
** These parts are subject to change. Ill add revision notes as needed.

Printer:

Reality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.4

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Supports are at your discretion.

Installation:
What you will need.
2pcs 3mm x 6mm Socket head screws. (this is what holds the mount to the CR-10.)
what ever screws you desire for your fans. I tapped the holes 3mm and used machine screws. ,
Electrical see explanation below:

My version
I cut the Extruder and Thermistor wires (measuring from the Hotend and Thermistor
+/- 4" and installed some Quick connects the kind used in the RC world. (Ill post some pics and part numbers) this way I can do a quick swap. BTW I solder and heat shrinked the ends.
I did add a similar connector to the factory Hot end . should I ever need to go back to it.

Install all the parts. you will need to adjust the Y axis 8mm (this is what you will lose.) give or take. fwiw the hot end does home right at the edge of the glass. so you lose +/ 1mm in reality.
the Y axis is easy to re adjust. you will need a small hex driver. loosen it set to desired position and your done.

Pics uploaded of the connectors I used. (3 of one style and 1 of another style. 4 in total)
Since their are 3 low voltage devices 2 fans and the Thermistor. I used the Deans Micro connector. they are small! be sure and wire the fans so that when done the 12+ side is NOT exposed when un plugged. Then for the Hot end. Deans Ultra. (the larger plug with spring clips to insure a good connection even under heated load. Use the female side on the PS end. solder it on at no less then 4" from the hot end. but a spare set and go ahead and solder on the spare ones to the factory setup. this way you can install the old setup in a pinch.

The connectors can be bought off any RC supply Amazon Ebay. etc... their DIRT cheap. a little bit of heat shrink and your ready for the races.

Other Notables:
I made the fan area holes just small enough that they can be tapped to 3mm, alternatively you can drill them out and make them pass through what ever you like. Just know they were not sized for some self tapping wood screw. the holes are straight thru and not tapered.
The mounting holes. were sized just and I mean Just smaller then. 3mm threaded machine screw. so they they are a good tight fit. The hex nut insert should fit nice and snug. Ill confirm but IF I recall a 20mm length should do the trick

The Auxiliary fan manifold. sits atop the main mount the idea is it falls into two alignment holes and then the bottom portion near the air outlet snaps into place. technically it should never need to come off once on. as the entire front can be removed even with the manifold in place. but depending on your detail or print precision. you may need to file to fit. or heck glue it on. and remove the pins. again it can be removed in place simply by removing the from hot end clamp.

I re calibrated my hotted using Marlins auto PID.
Its that simple. Best luck!

comments.text: Ok man, I finally got this mounted. The tip of the nozzle is about 10mm higher on this setup than my stock setup for some reason. The mount I printed was the same one you have shown here. I raised my bed to the point where the adjusters were ready to fall off the screws and the springs almost had no tension on them. So I thought maybe my -Z- axis limit switch was sitting higher. But even tweaking it all the way down as best I could (stock -Z- axis limit mount) it still couldn't get within 4mm. So I notched the mount for the limit switch to get all of the negative -Z- movement I could before bottoming out the travel. That only gained me 1mm at most. So now I am stuck wondering what the heck is going on. My CR-7 mini just went down needing a new motherboard. And now I have this so torn down I am stuck, Any ideas what I might have done wrong?
comments.author: WickedFog

comments.text:
pics might help. My hot end was a knock off of the real thing. Parallel to that I bought a real E3D re build kit.
and made kind of a hybrid setup So some real some knock off. but in the end. I think my Hot end is the same height as a real E3D.
and if not? its darn close. +/-1-3mm? pics o and measurements would be helpful to see where the difference is. I have 2 CR-10s bought at different times. they are for the most part identical.
comments.author: WickedFog

comments.text: I figured it out. To be sure homing the machine didn't crash into the bed I lowered the bed all the way down. When I first tried releveling the bed I raised one corner only at first. When I raised the other corner the bed raised more. But this makes me think... if we dropped the mount 10mm or so and lowered the -Z- limit switch to the absolute lowest it can be we could gain an extra 10mm of -Z- travel. I also think having the bed springs drawn down tighter would be better to keep the bed more stable. I am going to remix this design with a new mount and try it out. I want to print this fan duct out of ABS anyway if I can get ABS to print good lol.

comments.text: You can use the duct and guides together, the guides can be moved over a wide range to accommodate.  As for the guides, I used the copper pipe sections included with the filastruder, and some large washers I had lying around. description.text:
Description

This is a nosanding bearing oldham coupler for Tevo tarantula printer.
It is designed to be small and simple to print.

Printed parts list

1 x Top
1 x Bottom
1 x Bearing cross
2 x Guide
4 x Washer

Use the corresponding STL's for your bearings (626 or 608). Guides are the same.

Non printed parts list

X gantry mount: 2 x M4 screws + 2 x M4 T-nuts (same as stock)
Bearing screws: 4 x M3 x 12 mm screws
Bearings: 4 x 626RS or 4 x 608RS bearings. RS is for protection from dust. You could use ZZ or just plain unsealed bearings but those will collect dust with time.
Tools: 3 mm tap, 3,5 mm and 4 mm drill bits.

Functional description

This oldham was designed by me after seeing Vascojdb's design and seeing the advantages of bearings and no-sanding approach in an oldham. So the same goals:

1) Use bearings instead of plastic-on-plastic
2) Use the polished side of plastic that faces the glass bed, instead of sanding it
3) Almost no need to sand anything
4) Print all at once, no supports.
5) Minimum number of different parts.

After a question "why don't use common spinner bearings (608)" I made a modified design to fit those.

Printing tips

Print with low speed. Place the two guides at opposite sides of the build plate to give time for the plastic to cool. Use the drill bits to enlarge holes to proper dimensions. Use the tap for the bearing screw holes to not cause a stress in small bearing guides.

Installation and usage tips

1) Install bearings on the BEARING CROSS.
2) Mark a pair of bearings (back/left; front/left;...) to check the guide size to the corresponding pair.
3) Check if the guides can slide almost free between their corresponding bearing pair. They should face the bearings with the shorter sides. Sand the shorter sides against a flat surface if there is not enough clearance. Try to keep the sanded sides parallel.
4) Pay attention when mounting the guides to the top and bottom pieces. They should be mounted on the bottom printing surface - the smooth one. Also those pins fit very tight and if you need to disassemble them for some reason (additional sanding, replacement,...) it is best to not pry them but tap through the holes.
5) Fit the top piece to the X gantry in such a way that when the Zrod is free it will be in the centre of the hole in the TOP piece.
6) insert the Zrod into the bearing cross paying attention to the orientation marked in step 2.
7) Screw the brass nut to the bottom piece and screw it on to the Zrod.
8) Pay attention to orient the bottom piece in such a way that back/front bearings step on it and top piece steps on left/right bearings

Others

Designed in: FreeCAD
Attached files: STL and FCStd
Material: used PETG but PLA should be strong enough if not in a heated enclosure

Take note that I did not actually print and test the 608 design. Just redimensioned the parts to fit those. There should not be any problems since the other makes are all with 608 bearings but if You encounter any please let me know and I will make the necessary adjustments.

Please post your makes and if you have any comments/suggestions/... feel free to post a comment :)

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

No

0,2

50%

Notes:

Should be printed on glass or a very smooth surface so dont use raft.

comments.text:
This isn't an Oldham coupler...
A coupler is used to transfer rotational motion to another shaft that isn't perfectly lined up to the other either angularly, parallelly, or both. An Oldham is for parallel correction, not angular.
comments.author: DarkShadowX5

comments.text:
It is transfering rotational energy - from the gantry to the leadscrew nut, which prevents the nut from spining. The fact is that they are not turning around the leadscrew but it is turning inside them. And if the tongue and groove are longe a regular oldham could also compensate angular missalignment.
It does the job it is designed to do.
The point of your comment is? If you have suggestiion for a better name - just give it. Also dont forget to post to the other 64 search results for "oldham" here.
comments.author: DarkShadowX5

comments.text: Love the design. Really helped with my z-banding. Will post a made later. (have been meaning to do this for a while.
comments.author: jfaurbo

comments.text:
The goal of the original design from Vascojdb and also here was instead of sliding of plastic parts against one another to have a rolling of a bearing with cylindrical outer surface over a flat plane - the bottom surface of a part printed over a glass so it will be as flat as possible (almost mirror finish - no need for sanding it). There had to be guides so one pair of bearings will race only perpendicular to the other and transmit the restriction of rotation from the top part, through the bearings - bearing cross - other set obf bearings - bottom part - leadscrew nut. And if everything is printed, assembled and adjusted well the leadscrew should not touch any of the plastic parts.
So if you are going to remix you need to deeesign the parts so that the top part is printed on its bottom surface and bottom part is printed on its top surface (upside down). The guides should be just a bit wider than the bearing cross bearing mating surfaces so they could be lightly sanded and made smooth for the sides of the bearings to run against them. And to have a minimal backlash.
I hope your design turns out well :)
comments.author: jfaurbo

It can always be made bigger to allow more play but you should not build your machine so sloppy :)

comments.author: asahiGR

comments.text: Just made one to replace a much larger oldham adapter that had attachment points on the sides instead of underneath.  Gained back about 5mm X travel with this.  Looks amazing, works about as well as my old adapter, albeit without any sanding .  I've tried several oldham adapters, and this one has the least compensation of any of them; I only get about 2-2.5mm of potential compensation.  Not a problem for me, as my leadscrew is very straight, but I could see it being an issue for anybody that has a bent screw or a skewed motor mount.  Not a flaw, just a design tradeoff for a more compact unit, but I thought I'd throw that out there before someone with a wobbly leadscrew orders the parts, prints this up, and finds out it won't work for them.
comments.author: chantling

comments.text: I made one of these and after several weeks, the bearing cross began to warp under the weight of the gantry. I would recommend reinforcing the bearing cross thicker to prevent this.

comments.author: mdiorio

comments.text:
Logical design arguments - 608's are bigger, heavier, more expensive, the thing should be bigger thus more material and time to print.
The real reason - I was looking for a spinner and I had 626 on hand so I found this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2177567 bought some more 626's and made that spinner. Then when I made the remix I still had 1 626 and 0 608 so I went that way. I bought 3 more 626RS for around €0,50 each and €0,40 for filament - €2,50 total. There are several specialised bearing shops here so no problem with bearing supply.
I could make some minor modifications to the design and make a new one for 608 bearings also if needed...
comments.author: mdiorio

comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: That design will not compensate the ZWobble (movement of the ZRod in X/Y directions) which is the main purpose of the Oldham. Using the bearing versions alows for an X/Y missalignment/wobble compensation and also angular missalignment along the Z axis. Also remember - no or a minimal sanding.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I know but it is what he claims ! In fact his design is totally wrong, it is neither an Oldham replacement and is not even able to correct any axial misalignment !

title: Raspberry PI 2020 mount (eg CR-10, AM8, Tevo Tarantula, Tevo Tornado)

description.text:
Because of the fact that i had some problems with the VORON case (no holes or wrong diameter), i took the original case, removed the outside holes for mounting it onto a vesa mount, added six holes into the bottom part itself and now i am Happy with that design.

You can easily use some hammer nuts like i showed in one picture and mount the PI where every you want it on your printer.

Parts you'll need:

2-3 x hammer nuts (on my cr-10 i used M4)
2-3 x screws fitting into your hammer nuts
4 x M2.5x6 for mounting the pi on the bottom part
4 x M3x20 for mounting the top part to the bottom part

Do not use washers inside the case for mounting the case to the 2020 extrusions, you could damage your PI if you short some connections.

I powered the PI by using Pin 2 and 6 of the GPIO's.

This is a Raspberry Pi case, designed (as close as plausible for me) 1:1 with the mid 2010 Mac Mini.

(This case supports the Raspberry Pi 2 + 3)

the case is designed to snap together, except for the bottom feet, that might need some glue to hold it in place, but there is a little cut out on the bottom of the bottom "shell" for aligning the part. The case might also support a heatsink, depending on how tall it might be.

please note, that the case is not designed to support a fan, but there is a gap in the SuperDrive opening, so there can be samewhat an airflow.

for detailed help on how to put the parts together, please refer to the pictures.

(The MacPi Mini and tiny is compared in size in the pictures, the other model can be found under my designs)

if there is any flaws or problems printing this, please let me know ^^

title: Anycubic Prusa i3 Acrylic top strengthening

description.text:
Strengthening for the top of the Anycubic Prusa i3 Acrylic

Print both parts and put them together (sliding right into the left one)
Remove screws left & right at the top of your printer.
Now slide them onto the top of your Anycubic I3 acrylic and fix them with some screw left over from the kit for testing.
If everything fits well, take it apart again and put some glue between the left and right slide surface only and put it back on, fix it again with screws and let it the glue harden.

Now it should be a lot for stable while still being removeable.
I use mine as a platform for my bowden stepper motors.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8YO2OEsnj4D

This is an excellent (albeit, simple) organizer, but I needed drawers to hold 30 denominations of resistor, so I needed 6 compartments that ran the full depth of the unit (times 5 drawers). I'm guessing that most folks who order assorted packs of resistors from Amazon have the same issue.

I imported the original single compartment design file into OpenSCAD and added the individual compartments in a loop. I originally included the OpenSCAD file and gave instructions for rendering the drawer with a different number of compartments. After realizing that most people aren't nerds and may not want to get, install and use OpenSCAD, I have included STL files for drawers with 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 compartments. The OpenSCAD file is still there in case you want something different.

You can customize the number of compartments by opening the file in OpenSCAD and changing the value of numCompartments. Render, export, slice and print. That's all there is to it. Not difficult, just not something that I would expect a normal human to be happy doing. But then again, you're 3D printing by choice, so you're not exactly what most humans would call "normal."

The included generated "Deep drawers" and "Deep drawers_6 compartments" STL files are identical (6 compartments). The original "Drawer_1_compartment.stl" is included for rendering in OpenSCAD. You'll need that to make anything other than the versions the are included here. The other files are variations with differing numbers of compartments. The file name should give you enough information to know which is which.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

any

In OpenSCAD, imported the original single drawer design for its shell, filled it in with a solid cube, then dug out compartments in a loop.

Retaining rounded edges at the bottom of each compartment was an important feature because digging things out of these narrow cutouts with adult human-sized fingers is difficult otherwise.

title: General purpose drone canopy or surface mount enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a more refined version of a canopy I designed for use as a canopy for covering the electronics on a Tarot 650 drone. The flange is for surface mounting the enclosure. I didn't put screw holes so you can drill the holes the size you need, or the box fits the flange tight enough you may opt to have it slip-fit. The bottom of the flange is flat and suitable for 1/4" double face emblem tape mounting; so screws or tape.

Feedback is welcome. I'm very new to 3D design and printing, so constructive feedback will help me learn.

Printer:

QIDI Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed both halves in QIDI PLA (blue/org). The blue is good, but bright orange prints so perfect. I design with TinkerCAD and slice with Simplify 3D on a stock QIDI Tech 1 printer.

My settings are 205 degrees for the initial layer, 202 degrees for rest. I use 6.3mm aluminum bed with QIDI surface sticker that works perfect everytime as long as I wipe it with alcohol for each print, My bed surface temperature is initially about 60 degrees, but drops to 55 for the balance of the print. I pre-heat at 205/60 and allow the preheat to run for at least 10 minutes before printing.

author: fritzfisch

title: Rigid Carriage for V-slot Kossel Delta

description.text:
This is basically a stiff magball carriage for a Kossel V-slot delta printer, with 43 mm spacing, based on the Ultibots K250 / D300VS carriage.

For the 3W design view: http://a360.co/2yBcCaA
For the 4W design view: http://a360.co/2yvqQKd

I wanted to make it really stiff with a unbroken full frame, so I made wheel tensioning using a concentric spacer. I also designed a slot belt tensioning system where the tensioner is pushed through from behind, and endstop mounts that's mounted behind the carriage.

There's built in print support on the carriage and tensioner. Easy to cut off.

For the wheel kits use M5x35 screws and nyloc nuts.
For the belt tensioner use M3x35 screws and nyloc nuts

For adjusting the wheel tensioner you can use either a 11 mm or a 7/16" wrench

The Z-height is raised by 29.5 mm on the carriage, and another 5 mm on the endstop mounts, over the stock ultibots parts.

22-10-2017:
-Concentric spacer offset was changed from 1 to 0.5mm.
-Position of the socket for the concentric spacer was moved 0.25 to the center.
-I added a 4 wheel version of the carriage. This might lead to over constraint of the linear motion rail but I wanted to test it out, and it works fine. This gives a little more stability behind the mag ball end that is otherwise positioned above the 3rd wheel. It is of course a little heavier too than the 3 wheel version. The equal tightening of 2 wheels is also a little harder. My method was twisting the wheels and try making them have the same slip against the rail.
The 3 wheel carriage is almost as stable as the 4 wheeled so for a light effector (bowden) I would go with that.

I printed mine in PLA at 210 degrees c. with 25% infill.

comments.text: Great mod! I would consider using wedges for the belts. They are easier to assemble and more durable IMO. I like the high balls and the bottom mount tensioner. Definitely considerations for our next version of carriages!
comments.author: UltiBots

comments.text: Thanks, Brad. Wedges for the belts is a good idea! Next time I'm working on this design I'll se if I can put some in there.

title: Airproof valve with filament filter for plastic box

description.text:
Oct 14th. Loaded version2
The internal valve has been designed with a wider hole

These are two connectors to use in an plastic box to retain humidity out to keep the filaments in nice condition. The external part couples to a 6 mm pneumatic bowden valve. I ordered these from aliexpress http://tinyurl.com/yaln4pk8. Two M3-15mm screws with a round 5,4mm head (approximate) can be used to join the two parts together. In the interior piece, two hexagonal nylon 5,4mm nuts are used. I made a big square hole in the internal part to introduce a foam or a gauze to be used as a filter to clean the filament as a choice. The top hole is designed to add oil if desired to lube the filament. A thin rubber band can be placed in the outside part to ensure airproofness. Supports in the printing are not actually required, although it will improve the quality of the internal cavity, something not actually important. I include the original Fusion360 files for those wanting to change details.
The 0.15 layer height is important in the external piece since the pneumatic connection is threaded.

Español
Este es un conector que se usa para crear una vávula y ponerla en una caja de plástico para mantener los filamentos aislados de la humedad del aire. La pieza externa está diseñada para que se le acople una vávula pneumatica tipo bowden con rosca de 6mm comprado en Aliexpress http://tinyurl.com/yaln4pk8 . Las dos piezas se unen entre si con tornillos M3 de 15mm de longitud. La cabeza del tornillo M3 debe ser redonda y tener un diametro aproximado de 5,4mm, y las tuercas de la pieza interna lo son con nilón (para que no se aflojen) con un tamaño aproximado de 5,4mm. La pieza interna contiene un hueco donde se le puede acoplar una esponja o una gasa que sirva como filtro para limpiar el filamento, y la misma pieza tiene un agujero en la parte superior por la que se puede añadir aceite si se desea lubricar el filamento conforme sale y se limpia. Se puede usar una delgada tira de goma en la parte exterior para asegurar la estanqueidad aún más. El uso de soportes en la impresión para sostener la pieza interna es opcional. No es estrictamente necesario usarlo pero mejoraría algo la cavidad. Es importante imprimir con una altura de 0,15mm porque el alojamiento de la válvula pneumatica está creada con pasos de rosca.

Incluyo los archivos originales hechos con Fusion360 por si alquien quiere cambiar o modificar algo.

author: AntonioGPS

title: Nachtadler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Die »Nachteule« Leselampe ist eine klasse Idee. Einfach an die Brille clippen, und mensch hat überall Licht. Dumm nur, wenn mensch Adleraugen hat oder einfach nur im Bett keine Lesebrille trägt. Was dann? Dies dann. Dies ist eine Halterung, um sich eine Nachteule ohne Brille ans Ohr zu hängen, ähnlich wie eine Telefon-Freisprecheinrichtung.

Zu einem gewissen Grade ist dies an mein Ohr angepasst. Zum Beispiel die Größe der Lücke für den Tragus. Ich habe die FreeCAD-Datei beigefügt. Dort kann mensch die Größen anpassen.

There is this really nice mini flash light called the Nachteule (night owl) that you clip to your spectacles. (Apparently sold only in Germany.) Great for reading in bed, or just to get things out of the basement without turning on the overhead lights. There’s only one problem: what to do when you don’t need spectacles? So here is an ear clip with a small tray to clip your Nachteule to when you are hawk eyed (have Adleraugen in German).

This is, to a degree, sized for my ear. Especially the tragus gap. I included the FreeCAD file. Change the sizes in the drawings to make it fit.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Notes:

Ich habe meinen Nachtadler in PETG gedruckt, aber PLA sollte auch funktionieren. Die Auflagefläche ist nicht allzu groß. Bei schlechtem Halt solltet ihr ein Floß (“raft”) oder eine Krempe (“brim”) verwenden.
Wichtiger: wenn ihr keinen Ventilator zur Filamentkühlung habt, solltet ihr das hier nicht alleine drucken. Druckt noch ein anderes Teil, das mindestens 15,4 mm hoch ist, mit. Wenn euch gerade nichts einfällt, druckt einfach zwei Nachtadler. Wenn ihr einen spiegelt habt ihr einen fürs linke und einen fürs rechte Ohr.

I used PETG, but i think PLA should work almost as well. The standard printer settings don’t matter much, but you need reasonably good bed adhesion. If this fails more then once you may want to use a brim.
More importantly: When you don’t have a filament cooling fan, you should not print this alone. Put a second thing that is at least 15.4 mm high on the platter along with it to give it time to cool. Either print it along with that other thing you want, or just use a second Nachtadler. Mirror it and you have one for either ear.

Die Entwicklungsgeschichte gibt es in meinem Github-Repo.

There is some design history available at my github repo.

title: Mega I3 Filament Sensor and Extruder Fan Bracket

description.text:
This combines and replaces the already existing Filament Sensor Bracket of the Anycubic Mega I3 with a 40mm Fan Bracket to cool the Extruder.
I designed this because with some PLA Filaments I had the issue, that the extruder gear got hot enough, that the filament started to bend before going into the bowden tube.
I reused the magnet of the old Filament Sensor Holder which fits and sits nicely in this design.

The holes for the Fan are designed to be barely tight enough for 3mm wood screws to hold the Fans without the need of nuts. Screws with finer thread like metal screws will sit losely.

This is my first submission to Thingiverse so please double check settings and measurements.
Feel free to let me know how I could improve this.

description.text:
Hi!

This is a variation of the Rippled Vase Factory.

It's a customizable thing so i encourage you to play with Customizer and find your favourite vase.

Customizer allows you to set the shape of the vase and the distribution and some variations for the pattern used (some sort of rippled tile)

The Customizer generate TWO files, one with low resolution but useful when previewing the object and another with high-poly resolution that is better for print.

Prepared for printing in Spiral-Vase Mode you can print fast and get nice results.

Also included a ZIP with 40 STL's!!!

As always i encourage you to download the SCAD file and play locally in OpenSCAD.

I've made some pics for the files includes so you can choose easily what to print.

Hope you enjoy printing!

Have fun!

Models in pictures printed using the Anet E10 and the Creality CR-10
You can buy printers here (affiliate links):
Printers on Gearbest.com

Printer:

ANET E10 + Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 or 0.2mms

Infill:

No

Notes:

Print in Spiral-Vase mode.

Tips: Increase flow, reduce speed and use 3 or 4 bottoms. Another tip: If you have a small nozzle (0.3 or 0.4mms) can increase the 'wall width' to 0.5 or 0.6 to get a stronger surface

This is a Raspberry Pi case, designed (as close as plausible for me) 1:2 to the mid 2010 Mac Mini.

(This case supports the Raspberry Pi Zero)

the case is designed to snap together, except for the bottom feet, that might need some glue to hold it in place, but there is a little cut out on the bottom of the bottom "shell" for aligning the part (the middle part might need some glue on the bottom, on the inside, to help it to keep in place.

please note, that the case is not designed to support a fan or heatsink.

Most printers should be able to print this case.

for detailed help on how to put the parts together, please refer to the pictures.

(The MacPi Mini and tiny is compared in size in the pictures, the other model can be found under my designs)

if there is any flaws or problems printing this, please let me know ^^

title: Schweizer/Hughes  300 canopy for T-Rex 450 SE/V2 heli

description.text:
Hallo,

this is my prototype of Hughes 300 canopy for Align T-Rex450 RC helicopter. It is not 100% scale, because it is scaled to fit original T-Rex chasis. Parts are glued together by CA glue. Canopy is attached to original canopy pins. Therefore you must drill holes into fuel tanks and put in rubber rings from original T-Rex canopy. Helicopter is more stable with this canopy and it is easier to see its orientation. Here is also small video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XNPnNXI0vdI&feature=youtu.be

description.text: This is an example of my problem generating a hole.  I was hoping to print this, and not drill it out, but the skeinforge preview implies otherwise.  I have included the blender file as well as the STL file generated with blender.

I hope someone can use this to debug software or enjoy a funky bead, wheel or device feet. It might look really cool in PLA. Please see the discussion thread in the makerbot group to help with your design problems like this. http://groups.google.com/group/makerbot/browse_thread/thread/1cf0e94ef85df526

These prints, allow you to add extra rods to the printrbot making it more stable.
Wobble is the biggest issue I had to face, so adding two rods to the Y bed and two extra rods in the Z axis has helped significantly in reducing wobble, to almost none.

These parts replace
  • The original printrbot Z bases
  • The X idler and motor carriage
  • Adds an extra Y axis base with dual rods.
    • You will need:
  • Two identical Z axis rods
  • Two Identical Y axis rods
  • 8 Linear bearings
  • M3 x 32mm screws x4
  • M3 nuts x 4

comments.text: Most wobbles aren't wobbles. There may be different causes of the ribbing but on my PB it is was mostly uneven Z lift causing layers to squash and bulge. The main fix was the stabilize the z-motors. Note the the ribs don't spiral up but are a bulge going around the print at the same height.
comments.author: eddiema

comments.text: Nice job! Interested to hear what sort of wobble you were experiencing in the Y? My original PB shows some Z wobble in tall prints, so would like to see some before and after prints from you if you feel your mod addresses that. I'd certainly like to get rid of the Z wobble as it detracts from the finish of artistic prints.
comments.author: pocketscience

comments.text: Y wobble, from what I suspect was due to the fact that the belt was closer to one side, and the bearings having worn over time due to the bed being forced to go one direction more than the other.

I needed a replacement scythe for my son's costume and I liked K987's design. I scaled it up, sliced it and added connectors. It fits snugly together so you may need to sand the connectors slightly. It's designed to fit on a wooden handle such as a broom/mop stick. You may need to tweak it for your own measurements. Once printed, sand connectors, slide together and glue. Fill gaps with filler, then sand. I use XTC-3d to smooth before sanding and painting. Or you can print in a silver if you're not worried about any gaps. I'll post a picture to show what it looks like before working on model. So far, I'm happy with how it turned out.

The files are numbered starting with the piece that connects to the handle (#1), then out to the tip (#4). Right now, the picture I have posted shows #2-4 connected. I'll try and get more online soon. Completed length of all pieces connected is approximately 2 feet (roughly 62 centimeters).

I printed this on FlashForge Creator Pro.

author: MauroDelSanto1

description.text:
Inspired by Nautilus Gears by MishaT:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27233
Update 9/8/14:
I added a new smooth running seahorse gear version (v3). The new version does not latch into a closed position and is suitable to drive
with a motor, etc.
To clarify, choose the version of the gear based on desired action.
Gear v2 - Latching
Gear v3 - Smooth running
Enjoy!
Update 6/9/14:
Added DXF files, so hopefully people with laser cutters can try this out too.
Update: 2/27/14:
New Version (2.1) of the arm. I replaced the pins with simple holes. Use raw 1.75mm filament for the pins/rivets, using the methods described here for using rivets as hinges. Look at the section titled 'USING FILAMENT TO MAKE SOLID RIVETS AND HINGES' towards the end of the article :
http://makezine.com/projects/make-34/skill-builder-finishing-and-post-processing-your-3d-printed-objects/
I used a lighter instead of a heat gun. It's quite easy and much stronger than a printed pin.
Update 2/26/14:
New Version with stronger pins.... is a failure. Pins do not mate properly. I have a new vetted design with a simpler pin made from a raw filament 'rivet'. I'll post updated files and instructions on 2/27/14
Update 2/26/14: New Version with (hopefully) stronger pins.
Units are now in Metric.

Print two identical gears and one Left & Right side arm.
For a nice texture use 'Hilbert Curve' for the first and last layer of the seahorse gears.
Use raw 1.75mm filament for the pins/rivets, using the methods described here for using rivets as hinges. Look at the section titled 'USING FILAMENT TO MAKE SOLID RIVETS AND HINGES' towards the end of the article : http://makezine.com/projects/make-34/skill-builder-finishing-and-post-processing-your-3d-printed-objects/
I used a lighter instead of a heat gun. It's quite easy and much stronger than a printed pin.
Note:
The 'assembled' file is not set up to print in place. It is for visual reference only.

comments.text: Very fun to play with. I printed out the remix pin as well, but they didn't turn out to fit very well, so I tried a piece of filament anyways. The filament worked perfectly, It was a nice solid fit. I used a flat soldering tip to melt either side of the filament directly to the left and right walls until it was flush. My only complaint with this as a gear is its too easy for them to unhinge from each other and go opposite ways, other than that its very cool and everyone loves to play with it!

comments.text: I Must Say Very Nice Print! I've really enjoyed it! No overhangs to worry about, no support material, it's inherently resistant to corners lifting off, it's a quick print, it's very aesthetically pleasing and I can't quit playing with it. I really like the nautical/steampunk look it has. Though I had an issues starting out with using the filament in place of a pin. It worked but it was a little flimsy and the gears came away from each other easily. So I scaled it down about 3% length wise to get the gears closer and designed a snug compression push fit pin that works extremely well. No need for friction or solvent welding with the pin, to my surprise it just stays perfectly in place. The pin worked so well uploaded it since sounds like other people have also had an issue with using the filament as a pin. Just print it on it's side flat. As I'm writing this I just noticed your update about making a pin. Oops sorry, wasn't trying to beat you to it, just trying to help. Anyways, here the link to my pin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:366277/#fileshttp://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

title: Trimatrik Fridge-Magnet Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Description
A simple fridge-magnet organizer that can hold one small notebook, one cell phone, and two pens.

Requirements

  1. Printed part and magnet covers
  2. Self-adhesive magnetic tape or Neodymium magnets
    Note: Above a certain weight, 2x neodymium magnets will not be enough. Whereas, the magnetic tape would provide both traction and adhesion. Because of huge phone and notebook, I had to fix 4x neodymium magnets and 1x magnetic strip in my assembly. Now it can take ~500g of extra weight before sliding down.

Design Specs (Can be modified using included Solidworks file)

  • Max magnet dimensions: 15mm Dia. x 1.75mm thick
  • Max notebook dimensions: 110mm width x 10mm thick
  • Max phone dimensions: 78.4mm width x 10.4mm thick
  • Max pen dimensions: 15mm Dia.

Construction

  1. Print the part
  2. Print the magnet covers
  3. Add a dab of glue-gun glue to the indent and place one of the magnets
  4. Add another dab of glue on top of the magnet and place the cover on top
  5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 for the other magnet
  6. Add a dab of glue near each of the bottom corners. This will enhance gripping.
  7. See pictures for a better idea of the construction.

Timelapse: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gCkl50f3QNw

Hello, this is homework I had to do.

This is a little starlight i made.
It should give the illusion of depth by a diffuse plexiglas plate and optic fibers of different widths, light intensity and distance behind plexiglas.

This is the first project i made for a 30 watt laser cutter I made this project in Inkscape it has some flaws in it, but i am satisfied with the end result and hope that is will inspire people to make something similar. Materials used:
  • 6,1 mm (0.24") multiplex for the case and layers
  • 3 mm (0.12") plexiglas (nameless brand)
  • optic fiber wires 0,75 and 1,5 mm (0.03"and 0.06")
    • Electric components used of a cheap solar powered garden light (and later a single white led and a 3 Volt button cell.) The idea is that a diffuse plexiglas plate create a illusion of depth I have made this in an earlier project and want to see if I could make one in a wooden box and with less depth used. You might want to change the star-pattern because the 1.5mm fiber holes is used for the Capricorn constellation The plexiglas was clear and made diffuse with a sander (this was easier than expected). The design is multi layered, space behind the plexiglas is for the fibers witch have a varying difference in length and go to the second space. The second layer is nontransparent to stop light bleeding from the led, and will bundle the fibers to one single bundle, and in the next room is the light, there is not much room and in an earlier starlight i had a pvc tube to concentrate the light into all the fibers (with a bundle of fibers on one end and a PVC end-part with a led in de center on the other end) but in this project there was no room for that construction. The electrical part was a big flaw, before I started soldering it worked, in the wooden box it doesn't. I resolved this with some ducktape, led and 3V a battery (it will power the led minimal 1 day but this was a quick minimal electric component work-around). the flaws in the source file are that it should be 10 by 10 by 10 cm but is was +/- 20% bigger this is not a problem but the construction is not a very tight fit, if used with 7.5 mm multiplex (0.3") it should by fine, also there may be a cutting line in the second layer( where the fibers are sticking trough), but a little bit of glue fixed that, and I can't seem to find it in the source file ( i have very little experience in either Illustrator and Inscape. I hope this is easy readable because English is not my native language.

print_settings.Notes:: The toggle clamps may have to be printed with the tops down. And you will probably need support for the v1.

description.text:
Modular Prototyping Board Holder.

When prototyping a new project, I switch between different sized Arduino boards quite often. While I like using a normal breadboard, sometimes keeping everything together and stable can be a pain. Just attaching a USB cable can cause these lightweight boards to twist and turn.

I thought about purchasing a breadboard / board holder, but they don't really lend themselves to quickly switching the boards out. And they don't allow for mounting some things, like the IO breakout board for the Nano. So I came up with my own design.

The base of the system allows a standard 830 point breadboard to be permanently mounted (using the sticky tape that normally comes on them), and then a modular board holder to be clamped to the board with simple toggle clamps. The board holder has a standard outside dimension, but is custom fit for each board. You can print a single base unit, and then as many different board holders as needed for each type of board that you have.

I currently have board mounts for the these Arduino boards:

Nano IO Breakout Board
UNO
MEGA2560

I am using this breakout board for the Nano: https://www.itead.cc/itead-arduino-nano-io-shield.html

I am waiting on a some Raspberry Pi stuff. As soon as that comes arrives I'll make holders for those as well

The dimensions for the boards are taken directly from the manufacturer, and I've built in some extra clearance around them. But even then, boards may vary depending on how cleanly they were separated from each other. You may have to lightly sand the edges to remove any burrs, etc.

ASSEMBLY:

All hardware is 3mm.

Main Base:

1 each : MPS_Base.stl
4 each : Toggle_Clamp.stl or Toggle_Clamp_v2.stl
(Version 2 of the clamp does not have a recess for the washers)
4 each : 3mm X 8mm Cap Screws
4 each : 3mm X 7mm Flat Washer (omit for TC_v2)

Attach the Toggle Clamps to the board with the cap screws. Leave them loose to begin with. Insert a board holder into the base. Rotate the clamps over the edge of the board holder and tighten the cap screws until you have a small amount of friction. Don't over-tighten them. You want enough friction to hold the board, but still be able to move the clamps.

Board Holders:

Print out a board holder for each of the boards you want to use with the base. Attach the board to the holder with cap screws. Each of the holders has a mounting boss for each of the holes in the board, but you might not be able to use all of them (pin headers or trace clearance issues). All of the mounting bosses are at least 6mm deep, so a 5 or 6mm screw should work. Again, don't over-tighten the screws. We're just trying to hold the board to the holder.

Use:

  1. Place desired board/holder into the base.
  2. Prototype!

Printer:

Anycubic Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed these with 3 perimeters and 3 top/bottom layers.
I printed some of parts in PETG and some of them in PLA. I think either would work fine.

The toggle clamps may have to be printed with the tops down. And you will probably need support for the v1.
Designed in SketchUp 2017 Pro.
